Could you elaborate on how the comments were irritating? It's a complaint I've never heard before

WRITING.TITLE: I just watched 7 seasons of Blue Bloods
WRITING.TEXT:
In my free time, I've managed to explore some shows I've had saved in my list for a while, but never had the time to watch. One of those shows was the CBS cop show Blue Bloods. After watching the six seasons on Netflix and now having saw the 7th season, I've got some pros and cons.
For those who haven't seen it, Blue Bloods is about the trials and tribulations of a New York family with three generations in Law Enforcement, with Tom Selleck as the Police commissioner and Donnie Wahlberg as the detective as well as a normal beat cop and a district attorney in there as well.
Some of the pros are:
1. Its tackles sensitive topics; Most cop shows occasionally tackle some real world topic, but Blue Bloods makes it a regular occurrence where all four of the main characters encounter some kind of moral, ethical, or legal quandary that deals with a real world social or political issue (everything from gang violence, racial stereotyping, domestic violence, sexual harassment in the workplace, police brutality and everything in between) and later debate it with the rest of the family at their traditional Sunday dinner, usually where they try and see it from multiple perspectives, which is welcome change from most other cop shows today.
2. The characters are not all super dark: Another tendency of cop shows, and network TV in general is to have the characters have some kind of dark past, or some kind of lingering trauma or personal issue going on. Blue Bloods doesn't do that. Compared to a lot of its cop drama brethren, the show is pretty bright and the characters are more or less good people who try to do the right thing, which can be quite refreshing.
3. The characters are also surprisingly deep: A lot of cop dramas tend to have characters that are either wire thin or little more than caricatures. Blue Bloods is slightly different. A lot of the best qualities of the main characters can also be some of their biggest faults. A big example is that Tom Selleck's character is extremely ethical and rule oriented, however that can make him too rigid when when it comes to situations where most people would have use their influence or bent the rules.
As for the negatives:
1. Its not for everyone: The show, despite its attempts at debating certain topics, still has a clear opinion on a lot of things and if you don't share those opinions, then its not for you.
2. Donnie Wahlberg: Don't get me wrong, I like Donnie Wahlberg the actor, but I can't stand his character in this show. Whiny, stupidly written, and the living embodiment of plot armor.
3. Self-rightiousness: The show tends to go out of its way to make the main characters morally superior to the detriment of everyone else. Got a different idea on what's right and wrong? Too bad, Donnie Wahlberg's right! Caught in a situation that isn't black and white? Shut up, Magnum P.I. knows what to do!
4. Its corny: It tries to be funny, and its not. Its tries to be cool, and its not. It tries to be original, and its probably been done by 10 other shows in the last 5 years, half of them were probably on CBS.
I realize I might have put too much thought into a Friday night CBS cop drama, but the show kinda surprised me in some aspects.
I wouldn't put it past them, especially Nick Spencer.
It could still count. I've heard nothing but good things about it, but is it that cliched?

WRITING.TITLE: What is the most cliche filled show you've seen on TV recently?
WRITING.TEXT: For me, its a tie between half the shows running on CBS (anything with NCIS in the title, MacGyver, and especially Blue Bloods)

WRITING.TITLE: [Secret Empire spoilers] A question about Cap
WRITING.TEXT:
Withe the reveal in the latest issue of Secret Empire where spoiler another Steve Rogers appears out of nowhere, some people are theorizing/debating that the new Steve is the Cap from the Ultimate universe. I haven't read anything ultimate in a while, so I'm a little rusty on that universe's Cap. Can someone do a compare/contrast of the two Caps in regards to their personalities, ideals, differences ect.
Also, feel free to offer your opinions on the reveal and the theory as well.

I think the best way to introduced the X-Men/mutants in general is to just introduce them. Maybe say the aftereffects of Infinity War, which is bound to alter the fabric of space and time, causes the manifestation of the X-gene worldwide.
As for the X-Men, I would want them to go back to the basics, like with Spider-Man, where its the original 5 members, maybe with one or two additional members from the Claremont run.

WRITING.TITLE: Any advice about not missing Homework deadlines?
WRITING.TEXT:
With my semester wrapping up, I'm worried my grades might not be as strong as they could be, not because of my participation in class, but that I tended to miss deadlines for my online homework assignments. This has been an ongoing problem and i don't know how to fix it. I'm thinking about going back to a homework planner like I had in high school, but I'm not sure if that's the best or the most permanent solution.
Does anyone have any advice?

I think a good middle ground would be to say that Atlantis is located in the Pacific a few dozen miles off what is now the Hawaiian islands.

WRITING.TITLE: Does anyone remember the MTV Spider-Man show?
WRITING.TEXT: I used to own it on PSP discs as a kid and would watch them on plane rides. I recently caught it on Amazon video a few days ago, and it was surprisingly good despite the early 2000's techno score, the fact the Peter wore purple pants (that always bothered me growing up) and the recycled footage.

I both agree with and share that sentiment. Though, the visible part isn't a bad thing to a certain extent. For example, having a flag outside of your home or a small sticker or patch on something isn't a bad thing, but (for me as an American) when you're wearing the stars and stripes as everything from a three piece suit (yes, it happens here) to a bikini and everything in between, then it becomes gaudy and diminishes what the flag stands for.

WRITING.TITLE: [No Spoilers] If the members of the Justice League were in real American cities, where would they be?
WRITING.TEXT:
By this, I'm not asking what DC cities are analogous to real world one, but rather if the members of the JL(for arguments sake, lets use the New 52 league) were based out of real world cites, what cities could you see them being in?
For me, I could see:
Superman being based out of either New York or Chicago, but more so NYC.
Batman would be either in New York or Chicago, but I tend to lean towards Chicago maybe due to the history of crime we have here.
Wonder Woman would be in or near D.C. or Virginia
Flash would probably be in the midwest, but I could see him on the west coast also.
I could see Green Lantern be based out either L.A. or San Diego, given their proximity to military bases. Its also not too far of a stretch to imagine Hal rubbing shoulders with Hollywood.
Aquaman would be either in Miami or the Hawaiian islands, but I would lean more towards Hawaii
Cyborg is already based out of Detroit.
If you guys have any interesting suggestions for any non JL heroes feel free to suggest them.

Funnily enough, John Kelly was asked by a GOP congressman as to why he didn't wear a flag pin and he response was "I am an American flag". Just goes to show that true patriotism lies in actions, not accessories.

The only in depth insight we have is from his now wife. If it wasn't bad then, imagine what would have happened had that stuff went on for a few more months.
As for your other suggestions, Once an eagle would be great, Ghost Fleet would cool as something on Starz, and I had never heard about Blackhearts until now, and I just read the description on Amazon. It would be hard to watch, and maybe even genuinely disturbing given some of the stuff that happened.
Its getting a movie that's closer to the book. But I absolutely agree that a HBO miniseries with a GOT level budget would be awesome.

WRITING.TITLE: [COD] What would be your pitch for the story for Ghosts 2?
WRITING.TEXT:
In my opinion, the world of Ghosts is the one with the most potential story wise. I was really disappointed with the story of Ghosts mainly due to the fact that we weren't able to learn about or explore the setting. I also didn't think it had the best characters or the plot. Since the COD franchise is starting to focus more on developing personal or in depth stories, I'd be pretty excited if IW decides to go back to the Ghosts universe.
With that being said, what would your story pitches be for Ghosts 2?

Good call on American Spartan, but only if a network like HBO does it. I think that the story of Jim Gant needs to be left to interpretation by the audience and in the hands of a lesser studio, I could see them leaning towards one opinion of Gant or another.
Also, I'm surprised Horse Soldiers hasn't been picked up by a director or a network. I think its one of the most essential American stories of the last couple of decades and should be told, ideally by someone like Peter Berg or Stephan Spielberg.

Honestly, I would like to see IW take a shot at Vietnam. I think they've always been the best when it comes to telling cinematic, gritty stories as evident by the MW trilogy and, in my opinion, Infinite Warfare. I would love to see a Vietnam set COD in the vain of something like We Were Soldiers or Platoon, especially with the graphical leap the series has taken like what we've seen in the trailers for WWII.

If they were to go back to the Black Ops universe, I would want them to go back to WWII but focus on the covert operations that took place during the war, maybe with Mason's father (who was in the Pacific theater, but we don't exactly know what he did) as an OSS agent.
Like Cops meets The Office?

I miss The Unit, but you're right, the handling of the wives and the random paranormal stuff from season 3 derailed it for me. Unfortunately, it seems like any show in the vein of The Unit either has a very short shelf life (Last Resort and The Unit both had additional seasons planned, and both happened to be Shawn Ryan shows) or aren't that well made(American Oddessy, The Last Ship, Six, etc.)

WRITING.TITLE: What military event/book would you wanted to see become a miniseries or movie?
WRITING.TEXT:
I'm about to start rewatching Band of Brothers and The Pacific and I started to wonder why there hasn't been a miniseries in the style of those two since Generation Kill. There's certainly no shortage of stories that can be told, so which ones would you like to see get picked up as either a miniseries or a movie?
For me, the two biggest ones are the story told in Horse Soldiers by Doug Stanton or a series based on the Harlem Hellfighters.

WRITING.TITLE: Trump revealed highly classified information to Russian foreign minister and ambassador

WRITING.TEXT: To me, Superman being a dad kinda fits in with his character. He's been a role model to people for decades, and it only seems fitting that he ends up being a father. I also agree that Lois doesn't have a whole lot to do, but I think it all depends on the story ark.
I think we'll finally get the learning up of the missing 5 (or was it 10) years to the continuity with Doomsday Clock. With that, I think there's a chance Ma and Pa Kent come back.

My guess is that Connor gets reintroduced in phase 2 of Rebirth similar to Wally West or sooner. If he does, I would love it if they have him move in with Clark, Lois, and Jon and have him be an older brother figure to Jon. Or they could have him end up with Lex if he's still has the armor (which I hope he still does)
As for Chris, I don't know.

I think the inconsistencies in regards to continuity will be ironed out in the next few months, especially with Doomsday Clock on the horizon.
I like the conflict between Supes and Lex, as it gives a new dynamic to both, one I which doesn't get wiped away anytime soon.
I can also see how it cheapens the ending of New 52 Superman but to be honest, I say what we got afterwards was worth it.
And if you're right about Jurgens wanting a continuity he was more comfortable it, I can't really blame him. Continuity has always been problem for DC, especially with what, 3 or 4 retcons in the last few years. And at least he tried to maintain elements of both and did a fair job of it.
